instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Computer came in with liquid damage. Board seems very clean so spill had to be minor. DC in board diode was burnt. I replaced diode on DC Inboard and logic board turned on and booted. Keyboard was also damaged. Would not get green light on charger and no fan with old keyboard installed. Replaced keyboard and everything was working for a while. Started to reinstall OSX and during at some point the board just started to cycle 1 fan spin continuously. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is missing. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was there but was flaky. Now n missing as well and no spin at all. G3Hot 12.5V, PP3V42 3.42V, PPVINRTC 3.4V, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.5V, PPDCIN 16.7V. Missing both enables on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Pin 16 12.5 V.

Thank you.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Update - <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> pin 2 - 3.4V. Pin 6 - 0V. Pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> - 0V. Pin 3 - 0V. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>... no. Found <TRANSISTOR>Q7921</TRANSISTOR> was smashed (not sure how that happened, I think it happened when tech was changing keyboard.) It too has been replaced.

Thanks.


Update 2 -

Replaced <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>. I now have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> on pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> but 0V on pin 3? Shoudnt I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> now? Also missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> 0V in Diode.

SMC time?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> The L means it should be low.
Is it getting a green light now? I suspect corrosion under SMC,  give it a reflow.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok. Thanks for that. Yes, green light on. Already reflowed SMC. I guess I'll replace it? Have a good night man.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> 0V in Diode. Are you saying a short to GND or just 0V there?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Shorting out to ground now with <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>. Might be bad chip/soldering because once I removed it no more short. Will get back. Thanks.

Have a good day.

Update - Replaced <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> no short. .427 in diode. Still no fan spin.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Replaced SMC - same result


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> .124 in diode. .001 in Voltage.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is .004 in diode.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4V




Update - Replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Now <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> short is gone. I have .126 in diode for this. However now <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is getting super hot when plugged in to charger. Already replaced twice.

VREG5 is .004 in diode. (How the fuck did I get a short in <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> now! LOL! UGH..)



Thank you!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> gets hot there is a short on one of the LDO outputs. So VREG5 is a good suspect here. There is not much on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> line so this short should be easy to find.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah. I ran into one of your other posts about <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> issues. So I went ahead and looked at VREG5 and found short. Short was coming from <CHIP>U5805</CHIP>. Just curious... How do you think that happened? IDK...  Just finished putting everything back and fan is now spinning. I will install board and run diags and hope for the best.

I'm no Genius, but something tells me there was an easier way to do this, if I wasn't half retarded and better understood the acronyms and functionality of some of these IC's in the schematic. :)

Thanks for your help. Later man. Have a good one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I say this happened with you poking the pins of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> for testing. Look at what happens between pins 16 and 17....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok, Thank you.


So basicly I bridged pins 16 and 17 sending 12V to a 5V rail either with probing or possible shotty placement of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. This could probably have been solved by just replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> in the first place. But since I didnt realize I wasnt supposed to be getting voltage on ENTRIP pins I kept (frustratingly) messing around with it. Thank you for the informing me. I appreciate it.

1 more thing - 

Computer is now running and passed diagnostics, but I notice a delay in chime from when I hear the optical drive power up. Like 3-4 seconds. Any thoughts?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You just got very lucky the board didn't totally fry. A slip like this with a probe can be absolutely fatal.

I see nothing wrong with the last question you had. Case closed.
